On Friday, Spainâ€™s 3-2 home defeat by Italy featured a surreal situation with mistakes from the coaching staff at its centre. After half-time, Spain came out with only 10 players â€” and it was very nearly nine â€” because of a mix-up over substitutions.
Lucia Garcia only just made it onto the pitch in time for the restart â€” with her boots half on and laces untied. She had found out she was coming on at the end of a warm-up session that took place during the break, with virtually no time to prepare.
Esther Gonzalez â€” who had not warmed up at all â€” then had to hurry to come on, too. By the time she did, in the 48th minute, Italy had taken advantage and equalised for 1-1.
â€œI didnâ€™t understand anything,â€ Gonzalez said in a Spanish TV interview after the match. â€œI was sat on the bench and suddenly, with the game already started, they look at me â€” Montse and (assistant coach) Irene del Rio â€” and tell me: â€˜You have to go on without warming up.'â€

Del Castillo herself appeared to contradict this version of events when she said after the game: â€œIt must have been a miscalculation. At the start of the team talk, we already knew we were on the bench.â€
During half-time, there was a moment of tension between Bonmati and Tome, and Bonmati asked not to return to the pitch, according to dressing-room sources who wished to speak anonymously to protect their position. They said the coach did not seem to understand, and this led to the situation of Spain starting the second half with only 10 players.

This, along with other blunders made by staff in recent matches, has created a feeling in the dressing room that the coaching team is having to improvise.
Against Switzerland on October 31, four players â€” Irene Paredes, Ivana Andres, Gonzalez and Mariona Caldentey â€” were not able to feature because of a human administration error when uploading their details to UEFAâ€™s platform.

â€œWe have been sent a set of guidelines and we hope it wonâ€™t happen again,â€ Tome said at a press conference on November 21.
That same day, Tome named her squad for the two recent matches against Italy and Sweden. The call-up of Alexia Putellas was controversial, as she was injured.

The Barcelona forward had missed the Clasico meeting with Real Madrid two days previously and wasnâ€™t fit to play against Eintracht Frankfurt in the Womenâ€™s Champions League the next day. Putellas withdrew from the Spain squad on November 27.
It was another sign that communication between the coaching staff and players was not the best â€” and it is worth remembering that Tomeâ€™s first press conference as coach was already controversial. The vast majority of the players she called up had only days before repeated that they would not represent Spain until changes at the Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) were made, following Luis Rubialesâ€™ kiss on Jenni Hermoso.

Tome ignored this and called them up anyway. She said she had spoken to them, but the players publicly denied this was the case. They ended up returning â€” at least initially â€” because they were worried about potential sanctions for not doing so.
What followed should undoubtedly be considered good progress: the meetings with government officials until the early hours of the morning, the establishment of a joint committee where players will have a greater voice, and the removal of some senior RFEF figures. The waters are calmer now. The team also now has a new sporting director, Markel Zubizarreta, who has the full confidence of the players, especially those with whom he worked at Barca.
But Tomeâ€™s future in her position remains uncertain. Elections for the new RFEF presidency will likely be held in early 2024 and it is expected that there will be changes. All these misunderstandings only give a bad image to the national team. It is something that does not please a team that three and a half months ago were proclaimed world champions.
